As of 20th June:  Immunised residents and visitors, 2 years and older, must test upon arrival, day 4, day 8 and day 14 while in Bermuda.  Immunised residents, 2-years-old and older without a pre-arrival test, will quarantine for the first 4 days in Bermuda.  Unimmunised travellers will quarantine for 14 days in a Government Approved Quarantine Hotel or apply for an exemption.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210628230134/https://www.gov.bm/applying-bermuda-travel-authorisation

On 4 June 2021, elementary and secondary schools are closed for in-class learning with teaching online in the provinces of Ontario and Manitoba (Winnipeg and Brandon, 2 most populous cities, and some other areas). Many post-secondary institutions in Canada offered online classes during the past academic year and are continuing to do so for summer courses. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210602203546/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-students-wont-return-to-in-person-learning-for-the-rest-of/

On 14 June 2021, elementary and secondary schools are closed for in-class learning with teaching online in the provinces of Ontario and Manitoba (Winnipeg and Brandon, 2 most populous cities, and some other areas). Many post-secondary institutions in Canada offered online classes during the past academic year and are continuing to do so for summer courses. See CBC news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611165906/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/manitoba-covid-19-education-update-june-3-2021-1.6051900  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611170145/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/ontario-doctors-provincial-decision-school-closures-industry-over-children-1.6059812

On 18 June 2021, elementary and secondary schools are closed for in-class learning with teaching online in the provinces of Ontario and Manitoba (2 most populous cities of Winnipeg and Brandon and some other areas). Many post-secondary institutions in Canada offered online classes during the past academic year and are continuing to do so for summer courses. See governments of Manitoba and Ontario websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210617104635/https://news.ontario.ca/en/release/1000251/remote-learning-to-continue-across-ontario-for-the-remainder-of-school-year  https://web.archive.org/web/20210617104745/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/schools/index.html

28 June 2021 is the last Monday of the 2020-21 school year in most of Canada. Schools remain closed for in-class learning with teaching online in the provinces of Ontario and Manitoba (2 most populous cities of Winnipeg and Brandon and some other areas). Many post-secondary institutions in Canada offered online classes during the past academic year and are continuing to do so for summer courses. See governments of Manitoba and Ontario websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210626095723if_/https://news.ontario.ca/en/release/1000251/remote-learning-to-continue-across-ontario-for-the-remainder-of-school-year  https://web.archive.org/web/20210626095739/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/schools/index.html

On 2 July 2021, elementary and secondary schools throughout Canada are on the regular summer break. In the province of Ontario: “School boards are delivering virtual summer programming in July.” This is a continuation of Ontario’s policy to close schools for in-class learning with teaching online over the last 3 months of the regular school year. In the rest of Canada (except most of the province of Manitoba), schools finished the year open. Many post-secondary institutions in Canada offered online classes during the past academic year and are continuing to do so for summer courses. See government of Ontario website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210630201644/https://news.ontario.ca/en/statement/1000403/in-person-summer-learning-to-support-student-success-and-a-strong-start-to-2021-22-school-year

On 4 june 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. “Non-essential” businesses are closed in Ontario (province with the largest population). In other jurisdictions, businesses are open with restrictions. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210602203900/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-news-today-stay-at-home-order-ends-in-ontario-but-most-other/

On 14 june 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. “Non-essential” businesses are closed in the Porcupine Health region (city of Timmins north to James Bay) of the province of Ontario. In the rest of Canada, businesses are open with restrictions. See City of Timmins website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611171725/https://www.timmins.ca/UserFiles/Servers/Server_11976345/File/Find%20or%20Learn%20About/Media%20Release%20PHU%20Continues%20Restrictions.pdf

On 18 june 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. “Non-essential” businesses are closed for in-store shopping in the Porcupine Health region (including city of Timmins north to James Bay) of the province of Ontario. In the rest of Canada, businesses are open with restrictions. See Timmins Today and Globe and Mail news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210617105319/https://www.timminstoday.com/local-news/heres-whats-open-and-closed-in-the-porcupine-health-unit-region-3865896  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611183938/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

On 25 june 2021, in the Porcupine Health region (including city of Timmins north to James Bay) of the province of Ontario, “nonessential retail stores with outside doors are allowed to reopen with limited capacity.” Shopping malls, hair salons, fitness studios and other close-contact businesses remain closed throughout Ontario and some other jurisdictions. See Porcupine Health Region and Retail Council of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210626100713/https://www.porcupinehu.on.ca/en/your-health/infectious-diseases/novel-coronavirus/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210626102507/https://www.retailcouncil.org/coronavirus-info-for-retailers/provincial-reopening-frameworks/
Note from 25 June still applies.

On 2 july 2021, shopping malls, fitness studios and indoor dining remain closed throughout Ontario. In some jurisdictions, all businesses are open with public health guidelines in force. See Retail Council of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701094507/https://www.retailcouncil.org/coronavirus-info-for-retailers/provincial-reopening-frameworks/

On 4 June 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Ontario: “Outdoor limits for social gatherings and organized public events will be expanded to five people.” Nova Scotia (NS): “In-person performances are not permitted...Games, competitions, and tournaments are not permitted.” Some provinces are allowing public events with masking and/or distancing restrictions. See provinces of NS and Ontario websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210602205021/https://novascotia.ca/reopening-plan/phase-one/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210602211155/https://news.ontario.ca/en/release/1000161/ontario-releases-three-step-roadmap-to-safely-reopen-the-province

On 14 June 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Nova Scotia (NS): “Sports games, competitions, tournaments, in-person performances and spectators are not permitted.”  Ontario is allowing “organized public events with up to 10 people.” Some provinces are allowing public events such as ice hockey matches with spectators subject to masking, distancing restrictions and lower-than-normal capacity limits. See provinces of NS and Ontario websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611173801/https://novascotia.ca/reopening-plan/phase-one/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611175446/https://news.ontario.ca/en/release/1000279/ontario-to-move-to-step-one-of-roadmap-to-reopen-on-june-11

On 18 June 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Nova Scotia (NS): “Sports games, competitions, tournaments, in-person performances and spectators are not permitted.”  Ontario: “Indoor organized public events … are not allowed … Outdoor organized public events are permitted up to 10 people.” Some provinces are allowing public events such as ice hockey matches with spectators subject to masking, distancing restrictions and lower-than-normal capacity limits. See provinces of NS and Ontario websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210617110017/https://novascotia.ca/reopening-plan/phase-one/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210617110545/https://covid-19.ontario.ca/public-health-measures

On 28 June 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Nova Scotia (NS): “Sports games, competitions, tournaments, in-person performances and spectators are not permitted.”  Ontario: “Indoor organized public events … are not allowed … Outdoor organized public events are permitted up to 10 people.” Some provinces are allowing public events such as ice hockey matches with spectators subject to masking, distancing restrictions and lower-than-normal capacity limits. See provinces of NS and Ontario websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210626103308/https://novascotia.ca/reopening-plan/phase-one/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210626103058/https://covid-19.ontario.ca/public-health-measures

On 2 July 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Nova Scotia (NS): “Sports games, competitions, tournaments, in-person performances and spectators are not permitted.” Ontario: “Indoor organized public events and social gatherings are permitted up to 5 people. Outdoor organized public events and social gatherings are permitted up to 25 people.” Some other provinces are allowing public events such as ice hockey matches with spectators subject to masking, distancing restrictions and lower-than-normal capacity limits. See provinces of NS and Ontario websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701101420/https://novascotia.ca/reopening-plan/phase-one/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701101247/https://covid-19.ontario.ca/public-health-measures

On 4 June 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Ontario: “Ontarians cannot gather indoors with people not in their own households, but can do so outdoors to a maximum of five people.” Nova Scotia: “Outdoor gatherings of up to 10 are allowed under the current Phase 1 rules, but indoors, Nova Scotians are limited to their household bubble.” Alberta: “Prohibited indoors and capped at either 10 or five people outdoors, depending on whether you’re in a low- or high-case area.” BC: “Limited to five indoors (or one other household) and 10 outdoors.”  Limits are higher in other jurisdictions at lower covid alert levels. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210602211453/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

On 14 June 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Ontario: “gatherings of up to … 10” Nova Scotia: “Outdoor gatherings of up to 10 are allowed under the current Phase 1 rules, but indoors, Nova Scotians are limited to their household bubble.” Manitoba: “Private gatherings with people outside the household aren’t allowed indoors or outdoors.” BC: “Limited to five indoors (or one other household) and 10 outdoors.”  Limits are higher in other jurisdictions at lower covid alert levels. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210611183938/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

On 18 June 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Ontario: “Indoor social gatherings are not allowed, except with members of the same household (the people you live with) and caregivers. Outdoor social gatherings are permitted up to 10 people.” Nova Scotia (NS): “Informal social gathering limit outdoors is up to 10 people without social distancing and masks... Informal gathering limit indoors remains your household.” Limits are higher in some other jurisdictions at lower covid alert levels. See provinces of NS and Ontario websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210617110017/https://novascotia.ca/reopening-plan/phase-one/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210617110545/https://covid-19.ontario.ca/public-health-measures

On 28 June 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary: “Newfoundland and Labrador … a regular circle of 20 people [for] informal gatherings … Formal gatherings are limited to 100 people with physical distancing…[PEI and NB have similar rules and are coded 3] indoors, Nova Scotians are limited to 10 people without physical distancing...Ontarians cannot gather indoors with people not in their own households ... outdoors ... 10 … Saskatchewan … Private gatherings are limited to 10 indoors and outdoors...Alberta ...Indoor social gatherings are still prohibited...BRITISH COLUMBIA ...Public gatherings: Limited to five indoors (or one other household)” See globe and mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210626103650/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

On 2 July 2021, the rules set by each province and territory vary. Ontario: “Indoor organized public events and social gatherings are permitted up to 5 people. Outdoor organized public events and social gatherings are permitted up to 25 people.” Limits are higher in some other jurisdictions. See province of Ontario website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210701101247/https://covid-19.ontario.ca/public-health-measures

On 4 June 2021, in the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), bus transit seating is still restricted below capacity although limits are now higher than when NL was at higher alert levels. The NL limits are similar to informal practices in some other jurisdictions -- e.g., in Winnipeg, Manitoba transit users have been advised: “Only use Transit for essential trips, such as grocery shopping or getting to work.” See St. John’s and Corner Brook, NL and Winnipeg Transit websites, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210604124841/https://www.metrobus.com/covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210604131954/https://www.cornerbrook.com/bus-transit/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210604132144/https://winnipegtransit.com/en/rider-guide/news/winnipeg-transit-response-to-covid-19

On 14 June 2021, in the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), bus transit seating is still restricted below capacity although limits are now higher than when NL was at higher alert levels. The NL limits are similar to informal practices in some other jurisdictions -- e.g., in Winnipeg, Manitoba transit users have been advised: “Only use Transit for essential trips, such as grocery shopping or getting to work.” See St. John’s and Corner Brook, NL and Winnipeg Transit websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611185209/https://www.metrobus.com/covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611185259/https://www.cornerbrook.com/bus-transit/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611185433/https://winnipegtransit.com/en/rider-guide/news/winnipeg-transit-response-to-covid-19

On 18 June 2021, in the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), bus transit seating is still restricted below capacity although limits are now higher than when NL was at higher alert levels. The NL limits are similar to informal practices in some other jurisdictions -- e.g., in Winnipeg, Manitoba transit users have been advised: “Only use Transit for essential trips, such as grocery shopping or getting to work. Consider riding in off-peak hours if possible … Don’t board buses that don’t have enough room for you to keep a distance between yourself and others.” See St. John’s and Corner Brook, NL and Winnipeg Transit websites, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111410/https://www.metrobus.com/covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111521/https://www.cornerbrook.com/bus-transit/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111738/https://winnipegtransit.com/en/rider-guide/news/winnipeg-transit-response-to-covid-19

On 28 June 2021, in the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), bus transit seating is still restricted below capacity although limits are now higher than when NL was at higher alert levels. The NL limits are similar to recommendations in some other jurisdictions -- e.g., in Winnipeg, Manitoba transit users have been advised: “Only use Transit for essential trips, such as grocery shopping or getting to work. Consider riding in off-peak hours if possible … Don’t board buses that don’t have enough room for you to keep a distance between yourself and others.” See St. John’s and Corner Brook, NL and Winnipeg Transit websites, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210626114349/https://www.metrobus.com/covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210626114401/https://www.cornerbrook.com/bus-transit/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210626114427/https://winnipegtransit.com/en/rider-guide/news/winnipeg-transit-response-to-covid-19

On 2 July 2021, in the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), bus transit seating is still restricted below capacity although limits are now higher than when NL was at higher alert levels. The NL limits are similar to recommendations in some other jurisdictions -- e.g., in Winnipeg, Manitoba transit users have been advised: “Only use Transit for essential trips, such as grocery shopping or getting to work. Consider riding in off-peak hours if possible … Don’t board buses that don’t have enough room for you to keep a distance between yourself and others.” See St. John’s and Corner Brook, NL and Winnipeg Transit websites, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210701110333/https://www.metrobus.com/covid19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701110420/https://www.cornerbrook.com/bus-transit/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701110542/https://winnipegtransit.com/en/rider-guide/news/winnipeg-transit-response-to-covid-19

On 4 June 2021, the latest advice from the Chief Public Health Officer of Canada continues to be “reduce non-essential activities and outings to a minimum, avoid all non-essential travel”. Provinces and territories continue to ask residents “to stay home unless necessary for groceries, pharmacy visits or medical care”. See Government of Canada and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210602211453/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210603213840/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2021/06/statement-from-the-chief-public-health-officer-of-canada-on-june-3-2021.html

On 14 June 2021, the latest advice from the Chief Public Health Officer of Canada continues to be “reduce non-essential activities and outings to a minimum, avoid all non-essential travel”. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614105532/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2021/06/statement-from-the-chief-public-health-officer-of-canada-on-june-13-2021.html

On 18 June 2021, the latest advice from the Chief Public Health Officer of Canada continues to be “reduce non-essential activities and outings to a minimum, avoid all non-essential travel”. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210617112113/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2021/06/statement-from-the-chief-public-health-officer-of-canada-on-june-16-2021.html

On 28 June 2021, the Government of Canada continues to advise: “Stay at home as much as possible”. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210627202555/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks.html

On 2 July 2021, the Government of Canada continues to advise: “Stay at home as much as possible”. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701110752/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks.html

As of 4 june 2021, Alberta and Saskatchewan continue to be the only jurisdictions in Canada with no travel restrictions of any kind. Other provinces and territories have quarantine requirements and/or outright bans on interprovincial and/or international visitors. “In British Columbia, public health authorities have divided the province into three travel regions and asked residents not to travel outside their region or the province.” “STARTING MAY 25TH, NO SELF ISOLATION REQUIRED FOR FULLY VACCINATED CANADIAN VISITORS” to the Yukon Territory -- first “vaccine passport” for internal travel. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210602211453/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210603215222/https://www.travelyukon.com/en/travelupdates

As of 14 june 2021, Alberta and Saskatchewan continue to be the only jurisdictions in Canada with no travel restrictions of any kind. Other provinces and territories have quarantine requirements and/or outright bans on interprovincial and/or international visitors. “In British Columbia, public health authorities have divided the province into three travel regions and asked residents not to travel outside their region or the province. On 11 June, the leader of the People’s Party of Canada and former Minister of Foreign Affairs was charged for violating the province of Manitoba’s quarantine and public gathering rules after traveling to Manitoba to speak at a protest against public health rules. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611183938/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210612125607/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-maxime-bernier-charged-after-attending-rally-opposing-covid-19/

As of 18 june 2021, interprovincial travel restrictions (quarantine requirements and/or outright bans) remain in the 4 Atlantic provinces, Manitoba (where restrictions apply only to less-than-fully vaccinated persons, similar rule in Yukon Territory) and the 3 northern territories. Ontario, Quebec and British Columbia (BC) lifted their travel restrictions. Alberta and Saskatchewan never had any travel restrictions. See CP24 and CTV news as well as Province of BC websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210618133135/https://www.cp24.com/news/premiers-announce-regional-travel-to-resume-in-much-of-atlantic-canada-june-23-1.5471227  https://web.archive.org/web/20210618133719/https://winnipeg.ctvnews.ca/manitoba-officially-changes-interprovincial-travel-restrictions-for-fully-vaccinated-people-1.5466261  https://web.archive.org/web/20210618134119/https://toronto.ctvnews.ca/ontario-announces-it-will-reopen-provincial-borders-on-june-16-1.5469525  https://web.archive.org/web/20210618133758/https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/covid-19/travel/current

As of 28 june 2021, interprovincial travel restrictions (quarantine requirements and/or outright bans) remain in the 4 Atlantic provinces, Manitoba (where restrictions apply only to less-than-fully vaccinated persons, similar rule in Yukon Territory) and the 3 northern territories.   See globe and mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210626103650/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

As of 2 july 2021, interprovincial travel restrictions (quarantine requirements) remain in the 4 Atlantic provinces, Manitoba (where restrictions apply only to less-than-fully vaccinated persons, similar rule in Yukon Territory, NB requiring only one dose) and the 3 northern territories. See Global News plus globe and mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701111537/https://globalnews.ca/news/7951042/covid-19-n-s-changes-course-now-opening-to-rest-of-atlantic-canada-on-june-23/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210626103650/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

On 4 june 2021, travel restrictions between Canada and the rest of the world remain in place. “As of April 22, 2021 … Canada is suspending flights from India and Pakistan. To protect Canadians from the outbreak of COVID-19, the Prime Minister announced travel restrictions that limit travel to Canada. Until further notice, most foreign nationals cannot travel to Canada ... These restrictions stop most non-essential (discretionary) travel to Canada....You can travel to and enter Canada if you’re a Canadian citizen; permanent resident of Canada; person registered under Canada’s Indian Act; protected person. Foreign nationals, including United States (US) citizens, can travel to Canada only if they’re eligible...You must also have a quarantine plan that shows how you’ll quarantine for 14 days when you arrive in Canada. This plan is mandatory.” Members of Parliament from the governing party are calling for the border with the USA to be opened for fully vaccinated travellers, but no official response from the government as yet. See government of Canada and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210603215801/https://www.canada.ca/en/immigration-refugees-citizenship/services/coronavirus-covid19/travel-restrictions-exemptions.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210604133126/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-its-time-to-wake-up-and-reopen-the-canada-us-border/

On 14 june 2021, travel restrictions between Canada and the rest of the world remain in place. Canada and the USA are discussing when and how to open the border to tourists and other non-essential travellers. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614111332/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-trudeau-says-he-discussed-border-with-biden-but-no-deal/

On 18 June 2021, Canada’s Public Security Minister tweeted: In coordination with the U.S., we are extending restrictions on non-essential international travel and with the United States until July 21st, 2021.” See twitter.com, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210618150910/https://twitter.com/BillBlair/status/1405888242357092356

On 28 june 2021: “The border is restricted: Foreigners, fully vaccinated or not, can’t enter Canada by land for non-essential reasons like tourism, but supply chains … are still open for things like food, fuel and medicine.”  See globe and mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210626103650/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

On 2 july 2021: “Only Canadian citizens, permanent residents and some exempted groups of foreign nationals, like agricultural workers and international students, are allowed into the country right now. That’s only if they don’t have symptoms … The border is restricted: Foreigners, fully vaccinated or not, can’t enter Canada by land for non-essential reasons like tourism, but supply chains … are still open”.  See globe and mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210702143315/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/

As of 4 june 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health agencies follow this guidance to test individuals who report possible symptoms or are possible contacts. In some regions at some times, asymptomatic individuals have been encouraged to come forward for mass testing during outbreaks, but that practice remains the exception, not the general rule. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210604134024/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

As of 13 june 2021, PCR testing of symptomatic individuals remains the standard approach throughout Canada. Some lateral flow tests (LFTs) have been approved by Health Canada, but LFTs have not been deployed in any province or territory on a widespread basis as part of standard testing procedure. In the latest data as of 29 May 2021, 21.1 million LFTs have been distributed to provinces, territories and indigenous communities, but only 3.4 million (16%) have been used. 34.8 million laboratory covid tests have been conducted. With LFTs in use on a relatively limited basis and no LFT strategy articulated by Health Canada, the code remains 2 based on PCR testing. In a 12 May 2021 CBC news report: “Both Britain and Germany are providing so-called lateral flow antigen tests for free on a quota basis, encouraging people to pick them up in a pharmacy, test at home and then report their results online or through an app...CEO of the Ontario Pharmacists Association, said ""We need to get these tests in the community in a way that is easy to use with not a lot of cost or barriers to using them.""...Lucira [LTF manufacturer] said its tests should be available for Canadians to order online by June for about $75, excluding taxes and delivery charges. At that price point and online distribution model, they are not expected to be a mass-population solution.” Of all Canadian jurisdictions, the Province of Ontario is the one making most use of rapid testing (including LFTs) having advised on 10 May 2021: “Rapid antigen tests are available for screening people with no symptoms (asymptomatic) in: long-term care homes; retirement homes; schools and childcare centres in communities identified by local public health units and school boards; congregate living settings; workplaces without outbreaks in … priority sectors; certain community agencies working in locations identified under Ontario’s High Priority Communities Strategy...Those who test positive on a rapid antigen test must get a follow-up lab-based PCR test immediately (within 24 hours) to confirm the result.” Ontario’s strategy (which is NOT well-publicized) could be described as: lateral flow testing (and other rapid testing) available to asymptomatic people, who meet specific criteria, and all positive LFTs will be followed up by a PCR test. Weighing all information, 2 based on PCR testing of symptomatic individuals still seems to be the most accurate coding for Canada. See CBC news, Financial Post, Canadian Medical Association, corporate, Provinces of Ontario, Newfoundland and Labrador; and Government of Canada websites, archived:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210611152449/https://www.cbc.ca/news/health/health-canada-home-covid-19-tests-1.6020482  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611153217/https://www.cmaj.ca/content/cmaj/193/13/e449.full.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611152851/https://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/aurora-biomed-announces-health-canada-approval-for-fastep-rapid-covid-19-antigen-test-879563213.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611154443/https://www.360dx.com/infectious-disease/nal-von-minden-coronavirus-antibody-test-authorized-canada  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611154808/https://financialpost.com/pmn/press-releases-pmn/business-wire-news-releases-pmn/health-canada-approves-quidels-sofia-sars-antigen-fia-test-for-screening-of-asymptomatic-populations-with-serial-testing  https://web.archive.org/web/20210613163152/https://financialpost.com/pmn/press-releases-pmn/business-wire-news-releases-pmn/health-canada-authorizes-first-covid-19-test-for-self-testing-at-home  https://web.archive.org/web/20210611155903/https://www.crnnl.ca/sites/default/files/CMOH%20Memo%20re%20Panbio%20Test%20Results%20for%20Physicians%20and%20NPs.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210613232109/https://covid-19.ontario.ca/covid-19-test-and-testing-location-information  https://web.archive.org/web/20210613174440/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing/increased-supply.html

As of 14 june 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health agencies follow this guidance to PCR test individuals who report possible symptoms or are possible contacts. In some regions at some times, asymptomatic individuals have been encouraged to come forward for mass testing during outbreaks, but that practice remains the exception, not the general rule. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210613150750/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

As of 18 june 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health agencies follow this guidance to test individuals who report possible symptoms or are possible contacts. Some lateral flow tests (LFTs) have been approved by Health Canada, but LFTs have not been deployed in any province or territory on a widespread basis as part of standard testing procedure.  LFTs and other rapid tests are available to some asymptomatic people in specific circumstances (large workplaces in some provinces, arrivals at international airports), and all positive LFTs will be followed up by a Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test. PCR testing of symptomatic individuals remains the standard approach in Canada. See Government of Canada website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210618142733/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  ***Updated to add additional source confirming: http://web.archive.org/web/20210620092818if_/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/testing-screening-contact-tracing/rapid-tests-employees.html

As of 28 june 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health agencies follow this guidance to test individuals who report possible symptoms or are possible contacts. Some lateral flow tests (LFTs) have been approved by Health Canada, but LFTs have not been deployed on a widespread basis as part of standard testing procedure. LFTs and other rapid tests are available to some asymptomatic people in specific circumstances (large workplaces in some provinces, arrivals at international airports), and all positive LFTs will be followed up by a Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test. The province of Nova Scotia (NS) has deployed LFT rapid tests in many workplaces. However, PCR testing of symptomatic individuals remains the standard approach in Canada. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628112551/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628212250/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/like-a-pregnancy-test-rapid-covid-19-tests-key-tool-to-keep-virus-out-of-offices-1.5482397

As of 2 july 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health agencies follow this guidance to test individuals who report possible symptoms or are possible contacts. Some lateral flow tests (LFTs) have been approved by Health Canada, but LFTs have not been deployed on a widespread basis as part of standard testing procedure. LFTs and other rapid tests are available to some asymptomatic people in specific circumstances (arriving passengers at international airports, large workplaces in some provinces -- Nova Scotia, Ontario, Alberta). All positive LFTs will be followed up by a Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test. PCR testing of symptomatic individuals remains the standard first-test approach in Canada. See Government of Canada and CTV news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210702143958/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210702144234/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing/increased-supply.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628212250/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/like-a-pregnancy-test-rapid-covid-19-tests-key-tool-to-keep-virus-out-of-offices-1.5482397

As of 4 june 2021, all provinces and territories are doing their best to apply government of Canada guidance that when individuals “test positive for COVID-19, a public health official will ask you questions to collect important information about your symptoms; activities and travel you did before you tested positive; all the people you may have been in close contact with while you were contagious ...contact tracing. It's a key public health measure.” However, in some regions, contact tracing capacity has not always kept up with caseloads. No evidence as yet that these problems have been resolved throughout Canada.  See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210604134024/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

As of 14 june 2021, all provinces and territories are doing their best to apply government of Canada guidance that when individuals “test positive for COVID-19, a public health official will ask you questions to collect important information about your symptoms; activities and travel you did before you tested positive; all the people you may have been in close contact with while you were contagious ...contact tracing. It's a key public health measure.” However, in some regions, contact tracing capacity has not always kept up with caseloads. For example, after a recent outbreak of the Delta variant that may have started in a remote mine and then spread across Canada as workers returned home for scheduled breaks: “The Canadian Red Cross is now being brought into Baffinland [mining site] to help with contact tracing”.  See Government of Canada and Star newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210613150750/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210613150540/https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2021/06/12/how-a-massive-outbreak-at-nunavuts-baffinland-mine-sent-sparks-of-the-delta-variant-across-the-country.html

As of 18 june 2021, all provinces and territories are doing their best to apply government of Canada guidance that when individuals “test positive for COVID-19, a public health official will ask you questions to collect important information about your symptoms; activities and travel you did before you tested positive; all the people you may have been in close contact with while you were contagious ...contact tracing. It's a key public health measure.” After a recent outbreak of the Delta variant in the Waterloo region of the province of Ontario, the local Member of Provincial Parliament commented: “We need to put this fire out with accelerated vaccines, contact tracing ...These are urgent concerns ...” This comment suggests that contact tracing may not have kept up with the caseload spike in this region. See Government of Canada and CTV news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210618142733/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210618144001/https://kitchener.ctvnews.ca/we-need-to-put-this-fire-out-ndp-mpp-calls-for-more-vaccines-in-waterloo-region-1.5469517

As of 28 june 2021, all provinces and territories are applying government of Canada guidance that when individuals “test positive for COVID-19, a public health official will ask you questions to collect important information about your symptoms; activities and travel you did before you tested positive; all the people you may have been in close contact with while you were contagious ...contact tracing. It's a key public health measure.” With daily case counts much lower than at peak levels earlier in 2021 and recent isolated outbreaks subsiding, there is no evidence in the past 10 days of contact tracing efforts failing to keep up with new cases. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628112551/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

As of 2 july 2021, all provinces and territories are applying government of Canada guidance that when individuals “test positive for COVID-19, a public health official will ask you questions to collect important information about your symptoms; activities and travel you did before you tested positive; all the people you may have been in close contact with while you were contagious ...contact tracing. It's a key public health measure.” With daily case counts much lower than at peak levels earlier in 2021 and recent isolated outbreaks subsiding, there is no evidence in the past 2 weeks of contact tracing efforts failing to keep up with new cases. It remains to be seen whether contact tracing will be sufficient, if there is another wave of rising caseloads. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210702143958/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

On 4 june 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask when you’re in a shared space (indoors or outdoors) with people from outside of your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. Provinces and territories require adults and children to wear masks in public spaces. Exceptions in some jurisdictions in some circumstances preclude 3G rating. As of 4 june 2021,  11:22AM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 22,709,722 Canadians [60% of the total national population and 68% of the vaccine-eligible population aged 12+] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca (no longer being offered as a first dose). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments have not been distributed pending a quality control check. 2,481,530 Canadians [6.5% of total pop.] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations were initially targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions, adults in some neighbourhoods with high % of covid cases, pregnant women), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities/retirement homes first, then all seniors wherever they live). With all provinces and territories now making vaccinations available to ages as young as 12, code now at 5 = universal. See CTV news and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210604163830/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-in-canada-by-province-explainer/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210604164149/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccination-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

As of 14 june 2021,  2:06PM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 24,513,774 Canadians [64% of the total national population and 73% of the vaccine-eligible population aged 12+] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca (no longer being offered as a first dose). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments have not been distributed due to a quality control problem at the manufacturing plant. 4,761,574 Canadians [12.5% of total pop.] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. (Note that vaccination data do not include Canadians who were vaccinated in other countries while wintering at retirement homes or on essential business trips.) Within Canada, vaccinations were initially targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions, adults in some neighbourhoods with high % of covid cases, pregnant women), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities/retirement homes first, then all seniors wherever they live). With all provinces and territories now making vaccinations available to ages as young as 12, code now at 5 = universal. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614184449/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-in-canada-by-province-explainer/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614185220/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-federal-government-not-tracking-vaccination-status-of-returning/

As of 18 june 2021,  10:28AM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 24,914,373 Canadians [65.5% of the total national population and 74% of the vaccine-eligible population aged 12+] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca (no longer recommended). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments have not been distributed due to a quality control problem at the manufacturing plant. 6,180,593 Canadians [16% of total pop.] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. (Note that vaccination data do not include Canadians who have returned home after being vaccinated in other countries while wintering at retirement homes or on essential business trips. On the other hand, there may be a small amount of double-counting when residents live and work in different provinces and vaccinations take place at work.) Within Canada, vaccinations were initially targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions, adults in some neighbourhoods with high % of covid cases, pregnant women), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities/retirement homes first, then all seniors wherever they live). With all provinces and territories now making vaccinations available to ages as young as 12, code now at 5 = universal. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210618151835/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-in-canada-by-province-explainer/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210618151913/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-for-astrazeneca-recipients-pfizer-moderna-vaccines-now-the-preferred/

As of 28 june 2021,  3:46PM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 25,558,744 Canadians [67% of the total national population and 76% of the vaccine-eligible population aged 12+] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca (no longer recommended except in limited circumstances). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments have not been distributed due to a quality control problem at the manufacturing plant. 10,261,363 Canadians [27% of total pop.] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. (Note that vaccination data do not include Canadians who returned home after being vaccinated in other countries while wintering at retirement homes or on essential business trips. On the other hand, there may be a small amount of double-counting when residents live and work in different provinces, vaccinations took place at work and both provinces count the vaccinations.) Within Canada, vaccinations were initially targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions, adults in some neighbourhoods with high % of covid cases, pregnant women), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities/retirement homes first, then all seniors wherever they live). With all provinces and territories now making vaccinations available to ages as young as 12, code at 5 = universal. See CTV news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628210632/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccination-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

As of 2 july 2021,  10:31AM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 25,673,926 Canadians [68% of the total national population and 77% of the vaccine-eligible population aged 12+] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca (no longer recommended except in limited circumstances). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments have not been distributed due to a quality control problem at the manufacturing plant. 12,080,469 Canadians [32% of total pop.] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. (Note that vaccination data do not include Canadians who returned home after being vaccinated in other countries while wintering at retirement homes or on essential business trips. On the other hand, there may be a small amount of double-counting when residents live and work in different provinces, vaccinations took place at work and both provinces count the vaccinations.) Within Canada, vaccinations were initially targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions, adults in some neighbourhoods with high % of covid cases, pregnant women), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities/retirement homes first, then all seniors wherever they live). With all provinces and territories now making vaccinations available to ages as young as 12, code at 5 = universal. See CTV news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210702150910/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccination-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

Effective 2 june 2021, the province of Nova Scotia (NS) relaxed covid restrictions in long-term care homes. “Outdoor social visits are permitted for all residents...Residents who are fully vaccinated may be visited indoors or outdoors by specialized workers (this includes hair stylists, legal counsel, etc.)...Family members, friends and Designated Caregivers are permitted to transport a resident to a medical/dental appointment...two Designated Caregivers may visit a resident at the same time, regardless of immunization status of the resident. Immunization is recommended for Designated Caregivers, but is not mandatory” Other provinces had already relaxed restrictions in long-term care homes now that almost all residents have been vaccinated. Corrected to 2G, after initially maintaining 3T code. See province of NS website, archived:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614193503/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/docs/Guidelines-for-Long-Term-Care-Visits.pdf
Corrected to 2G after initially coded as 3T. See note for 2 June.

On 4 june 2021, the provincial and territorial governments continue to be responsible for regulating long-term care (LTC) homes with the government of Canada providing guidance to protect residents and staff from covid-19. Provinces and territories have relaxed restrictions in long-term care homes now that almost all residents have been vaccinated.  See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210604153236/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevent-control-covid-19-long-term-care-homes.html

On 14 june 2021, the provincial and territorial governments continue to be responsible for regulating long-term care (LTC) homes with the government of Canada providing guidance to protect residents and staff from covid-19. Provinces and territories have relaxed restrictions in long-term care homes now that almost all residents have been vaccinated. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614185953/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevent-control-covid-19-long-term-care-homes.html

On 18 june 2021, the provincial and territorial governments continue to be responsible for regulating long-term care (LTC) homes with the government of Canada providing guidance to protect residents and staff from covid-19. Provinces and territories have relaxed restrictions in long-term care homes now that most residents are fully vaccinated. E.g., Ontario’s rules: “As of June 9, residents of long-term care who have been fully vaccinated against COVID-19 can leave their homes for day and overnight trips...brief hugs can now take place regardless of the vaccination status of residents and visitors ... Where both the resident and visitors are fully immunized, close physical contact, including hand holding, can now take place safely… For residents who have mobility or health issues, they are now allowed to have one visitor inside their facility, in addition to an essential caregiver”. See Government of Canada and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210618144636/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevent-control-covid-19-long-term-care-homes.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210618145942/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/covid-19-ontario-june-3-2021-updated-vaccine-guidance-1.6051449

On 28 june 2021, the provincial and territorial governments continue to be responsible for regulating long-term care (LTC) homes with the government of Canada providing guidance to protect residents and staff from covid-19. Provinces and territories have relaxed restrictions in long-term care homes -- e.g., Ontario’s rules: “As of June 9, residents of long-term care who have been fully vaccinated against COVID-19 can leave their homes for day and overnight trips...brief hugs can now take place regardless of the vaccination status of residents and visitors ... Where both the resident and visitors are fully immunized, close physical contact, including hand holding, can now take place safely… For residents who have mobility or health issues, they are now allowed to have one visitor inside their facility, in addition to an essential caregiver”. See Governments of Canada and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628114802/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevent-control-covid-19-long-term-care-homes.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210618145942/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/covid-19-ontario-june-3-2021-updated-vaccine-guidance-1.6051449

On 2 july 2021, the provincial and territorial governments continue to be responsible for regulating long-term care (LTC) homes with the government of Canada providing guidance to protect residents and staff from covid-19. Provinces and territories have relaxed earlier restrictions in long-term care homes -- e.g., Ontario’s rules: “Outdoor visits -- Five people: resident, two caregivers, two visitors; Indoor visits -- One caregiver and one general visitor; Personal care services -- Not permitted”. See Governments of Canada and Ontario websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210702114453/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevent-control-covid-19-long-term-care-homes.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210702114904/https://www.ontario.ca/page/covid-19-information-visitors-long-term-care-homes

‘As of June 14, 2021, 34 states in the United States had no school closure order in effect due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Meanwhile, 13 states had ordered schools open.’    https://web.archive.org/web/20210705163819/https://www.statista.com/statistics/1103071/covid-19-school-closures-state-us/

No policy change found.     An executive order issued by Gov. Kevin Stitt on March 12 lifted all statewide restrictions on events and residents. This includes any occupancy restrictions for offices.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210607215752/https://www.northstarmeetingsgroup.com/News/Industry/Coronavirus-states-cities-reopening-COVID-19-new-cases#Oklahoma    https://web.archive.org/web/20210425023830/https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1992.pdf (previous order which was replaced by the order below)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425030825/https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1984.pdf (new order which makes no mention of any restrictions to residents or offices anymore)

As of June 28, ‘Hawaii permits events with up to 10 people indoors and 25 people outdoors. In New Orleans, gatherings are capped at 250 people indoors and 500 people outdoors. In New York, measures remain for large indoor event venues that can host more than 5,000 people. In Puerto Rico, events can take place at 75 percent capacity, with attendees providing a negative Covid-19 test result or proof of vaccination. In Washington, Events of up to 50 percent capacity or 400 people are permitted indoors under the phase three guidelines. Outdoor gatherings are limited to 400 people. All capacity restrictions will be lifted on June 30.’    https://web.archive.org/web/20210705165150/https://www.northstarmeetingsgroup.com/News/Industry/Coronavirus-states-cities-reopening-COVID-19-new-cases
